awd_titl_txt: ATD: Scanning Dynamic Spatial-Temporal Discrete Events for Threat Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
The overarching research objective of this project is to develop a statistical framework for detecting anomalies from spatial-temporal discrete event data. Nowadays, a large volume of such event data dispersed over space and time are becoming increasingly available in a wide variety of applications, such as human activity data, social network data, and crime data. The observations of the discrete events can occur in continuous time and locations, and there can be a complex text description of such events. The discrete event data contain rich correlation and causal information, which can potentially be used to infer the dynamics of the underlying systems and detect threats. The project aims to develop statistical methods to harvest this potential in threat detection using discrete events and address the algorithmic and computational challenges. The developed methods will go beyond the status-quo model estimation by considering more general statistical inference problems such as hypothesis tests and likelihood-based inference. The developed methods are general and can be used for various discrete event data. The project will specifically demonstrate the effectiveness of the developed methods on a large-scale crime dataset collected by the Atlanta Police Department. 

Recently, point process models have been proven an effective model for capturing the correlation structure in discrete events. While much success has been achieved in estimating the self-exciting spatial-temporal point process models, it remains unclear how one can perform anomaly detection leveraging these models, since (1) detection (which can be cast as hypothesis test) is inherently different from estimation, which involves different kinds of statistics and performance metrics; (2) in various situations, there is a large number of discrete events over broad spatial areas, and the goal is to detect a small cluster of related events, which amounts to "finding a needle in a haystack", thus there is a need to develop powerful and computationally efficient statistics; (3) the normal or reference state can be complex and dynamic and methods need to adapt to the slowly time-varying normal state. The project will address these challenges and provide answers to two related fundamental questions: how to detect clusters of correlated events from a large amount of data using the point process model, and how to estimate time-varying background normal pattern. The proposed work will advance the state-of-art for scan statistic research and build a novel connection between pseudo-likelihood estimation and reinforcement learning. The developed methods will be tested in a specific application of crime data analysis. The proposed education activities will involve students at all levels in rigorous mathematical and statistical training and gain hands-on data analysis skills.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The availability of event data dispersed over space and time has significantly increased in various applications, such as social network data, human activity data, seismic events, and crime data. Streaming event data is characterized by continuous time and location observations, providing complex correlation and causal information that can be leveraged to infer the dynamics of underlying systems and identify potential threats. Spatial-temporal marked point processes have emerged as a valuable model for discrete events, where discrete events exhibit temporal and spatial dependence. Self-exciting spatial-temporal point processes capture this dependence and have found application in seismological models of earthquakes, crime modeling, and social networks. However, a lack of available tools for statistical inference and powerful models that can represent complex real data and capture intricate spatio-temporal dependence has hindered progress in this area.


This research project focuses on developing methods for statistical inference and modeling tools essential for detecting threats in discrete events data from sources such as social media, police reports, and financial transaction records. The research deliverables significantly advance the frontier of Hawkes network models, including (i) statistical inference techniques such as online change-point detection, sequential confidence sets, and goodness-of-fit tests; (ii) a new model and representation for spatio-temporal point processes to account for complex spatio-temporal dependence in real data; and (iii) more efficient learning algorithms beyond maximum-likelihood estimation that are robust to model mismatch. The research findings and results have been disseminated to communities by publishing in conferences and journals and presented at research seminars. All manuscripts of papers are available on arXiv, and related codes are accessible online. The PI has organized a Special Issue in a leading journal in the field.


The project integrates education with research and provides research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students. The PI has mentored several undergraduate students doing research related to the projects and involved them in publishing papers. The project has supported several Ph.D. students, including female students; three have graduated and become tenure-track faculty members. The PI has led students to participate in the ATD Data Competition challenge. The project also impacts science through the PI's collaboration with geophysicists at Georgia Tech to apply the methods for seismic event data modeling. The project has an educational impact: the PI has developed an online course entitled "Computational Data Analysis," a graduate-level course that teaches students the foundations of computational statistics and machine learning, making the course more accessible to students with diverse backgrounds. The PI has participated in various outreach educational activities by organizing Georgia Statistics Day in 2019, co-organizing the Foundation in Data Science Summer School, and participating in the Women in Information Theory event at ISIT as a faculty host, providing career advice and support to female students and early-career professionals.
